Unnamed: 2: Materials processed and created by humans

Standard rectangular block or tablet bonded on mortar joints in a regular arrangement or pattern for strength or decoration, baked. Made from clay or brick earth which may contain varying quantities of chalk, lime or iron oxide which effect colour or density.
A block made of cement and coal cinders/ashes
Aggregate, cement and mortar combined with structural elements of iron or steel mesh or rod reinforcement to form stonelike masses for load bearing, structural building work

Composed of sand, stones or other aggregate and cement mixed with water which sets in a hard mass. The material is usually associated with modern building but was developed by Romans where cement was obtained from quicklime
A thin sheet made of metal, formed with alternating ridges and troughs
A hard, lustrous, transparent and brittle susbstance produced by fusing sand with soda and one or more ingredient (lime, alumina or others)
A strong and hard silvery-grey metal
Generally hard and strong material characterized by its high density, malleability, ductility and good conduction of heat and electricity
Soil, sand or other earthy matter, can bonded with straw or other binding material. Sundried in shaped or moulded blocks, forming mud bricks.
Soil, sand or other earthy matter, can bonded with straw or other binding material.
A piece of rock or hard mineral hewn or chiseled to shape
A piece of rock or hard mineral roughly shaped/worked
Hard, unglazed, brown, versatile earthenware which can be used as a tile or moulded into statuary. Used in a structural or semi-structural context as a moulded hollow block.
Ceramic tile with glaze
Ceramic tile
Ceramic tile without glaze
A general term for the weatherproof coat on the external and internal walls of a building. It can be used both as protective and decorative layer.
Render constituted by a mixture of sand and cement. It can be fine or coarse, textured or smooth, natural or colored.
Use of rubble stones
FISH: Smooth rendering applied to the exterior of buildings which may be incised to suggest coursed masonry. Made of lime and sand or brick dust, and more recently, cement.
A black mineral pitch.
Earth or clay suitable for making bricks.
A colourless or white mineral (sometimes coloured by impurities) used in the manufacture od cement, plaster, paint and others.
A mixture of cement with sand and water used for bonding stones or bricks.
A mixture of unspecified materials and water used for bonding stones or bricks.
Uneven stones set in mortar in an irregular way (not according regular courses).
Other materials not listed above
Unknown
